p: Animals are usually subjected to GM for many purposes such as making them leaner with faster growth rates, requiring less food, and having special characteristics, such as increased milk production in dairy animals and growth performance in poultry [ 51, 52]. These modifications again lead to improved productivity and lower costs for farmers and consumer, respectively. The U.S. Department of Agriculture and European Food Safety Authority are currently assessing various strategies of animal cloning for food products. Transgenic animals seem to be the next big step in cloning. However, it is not clear whether people will consider cloned animals as genetically modified foods [ 53].
